item.title: Mortgage Rates in the US Fall for a Fourth Week, Hitting 6.77%
item.description: Mortgage rates in the US fell for a fourth straight week.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Wong

media:content.media:description: Residential homes in Hercules, California, US, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. The Mortgage Bankers Association is scheduled to release mortgage applications figures on June 12.

item.title: Nigeria’s Tinubu Signs New Tax Laws in Latest Reform Push
item.description: Nigerian President Bola Tinubu has signed four new tax laws, marking the latest chapter in his push to reform the economy of Africa’s most populous nation.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo, Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: Bola Ahmed Tinubu

item.title: Majority of Fed Officials Leaning Against July Interest-Rate Cut
item.description: A flurry of Federal Reserve officials this week made clear they’ll need a few more months to gain confidence that tariff-driven price hikes won’t raise inflation in a persistent way.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Construction on the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. The Federal Reserve unveiled plans to roll back an important capital rule that big banks have said limits their ability to hold more Treasuries and act as intermediaries in the $29 trillion market.

item.title: Zambia to Borrow Extra $624 Million From Domestic Market in 2025
item.description: Zambia will borrow an additional 14.8 billion kwacha ($624 million) from the domestic market to cover a bigger-than-expected shortfall in this year’s budget, Finance Minister Situmbeko Musokotwane said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill, Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: The city skyline of Lusaka, Zambia.

item.title: Bailey Says Labour’s Payroll Tax Complicates Inflation Fight
item.description: The Labour government’s payroll tax is costing the UK jobs, depressing workers’ earnings and pushing up food prices, Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said as he warned that the risks to inflation remain “two-sided.”
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey at the BCC Global Annual Conference in London. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: Global Goods Trade Gains as Tariff Fears Speed Imports, WTO Says
item.description: Global merchandise trade accelerated in the World Trade Organization’s latest assessment, with a surge in imports tied to tariff stockpiling outweighing a slowdown in export orders.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: Loaded container ships at Felixstowe port in Felixstowe, UK, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. The UK doesn’t plan to use a get-out clause to override her fiscal rules, even as the US tariff war roiled global markets, forcing down the pound and UK gilts. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: US Pending Home-Sales Pick Up in May, With Gains Across Regions
item.description: Pending sales of previously owned homes in the US picked up in May after a sharp decline a month earlier, although overall activity remained subdued headed into summer.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: A house under contract in Pasadena, California.

item.title: US Merchandise-Trade Deficit Unexpectedly Widens on Exports Drop
item.description: The US merchandise-trade deficit unexpectedly widened in May on the biggest drop in exports since the onset of the pandemic, while imports were little changed.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

media:content.media:description: The shortfall in goods trade grew 11.1% to $96.6 billion, Commerce Department data showed. Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

item.title: US GDP Revised Lower as Consumers Slash Services Spending
item.description: US consumer spending grew in the first quarter at the weakest pace since the onset of the pandemic on a sharp deceleration in outlays for a variety of services.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Boesler

item.title: OpenAI CEO, Bank Officials to Speak at Fed Bank-Capital Meeting
item.description: The Federal Reserve outlined the agenda for its July 22 conference on banks’ capital requirements, which will feature discussions on the Basel III endgame, the stress testing framework, the capital surcharge for the largest lenders and leverage requirements.
item.dc:creator: Megan Howard

media:content.media:description: Sam Altman Photographer: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says Muted Tariff Impact May Open Door to Cut in Fall
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said she’s seeing increasing evidence that tariffs may not lead to a large or sustained inflation surge, helping bolster the case for a rate cut in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva, Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: President of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Mary Daly

item.title: Recurring US Jobless Claims Jump to Highest Since November 2021
item.description: Recurring applications for US unemployment benefits rose to the highest since November 2021, extending a sharp increase over the past 1 1/2 month and signaling more people are staying out of work for longer.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Job seekers attend a job fair in Los Angeles. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

item.title: Pakistan Eyes US Trade Deal Soon in Fast-Moving Talks
item.description: Pakistan said trade talks with the US could wrap up next week, as it offers to boost American imports, particularly cotton, amid unusually fast-moving negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider

media:content.media:description: Cotton modules before processing for shipment in Bishop, Texas. Photographer: Eddie Seal/Bloomberg

item.title: Barkin Says Fed Should Wait for Clarity Before Adjusting Rates
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Tom Barkin said he expects tariffs will put upward pressure on prices, and with so much still uncertain, the central bank should wait for more clarity before adjusting interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Reade Pickert, Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Tom Barkin, president of the Richmond Fed

item.title: India Rate Cuts Still on Table, Says Hawkish Policy-Setter
item.description: A relatively hawkish member of the Indian central bank’s interest rate-setting panel said there is room for borrowing costs to come down, despite a shift in stance in the last policy indicating a tightening bias.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

item.title: Spring Housing Market Is a Bust With US Hit by ‘Double Whammy’
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at the dour state of the US housing market. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Japan’s Trade Talks With US Bog Down Over Auto Tariffs
item.description: Now seems like a good time for a reminder that in trade fight club, there are a couple of rules.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: South African Consumer Confidence Recovers in Second Quarter
item.description: South African consumer confidence recovered in the second quarter as a proposed increase in consumer taxes was scrapped and an impasse in the coalition government over the budget ended.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near the Victoria Wharf shopping mall in the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront neighborhood in Cape Town. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: Treasuries Rally, Dollar Slumps as Trump Eyes Powell Successor
item.description: The dollar fell and US Treasuries rallied after a report that President Donald Trump is considering naming Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s successor well before the incumbent’s term is scheduled to end next May.
item.dc:creator: Alice Atkins, Ruth Carson

item.title: Iran Caused $3 Billion of Damage With Missile Strikes on Israel
item.description: Israel has estimated the cost of damages incurred during its 12-day war with Iran at 10 billion shekels ($3 billion), with funds needed both to repair missile-hit buildings and pay compensation to local businesses.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Rescuers amid the debris of damaged buildings in Tel Aviv following an Iranian missile attack.

item.title: How Vibes Became a Nearly Undefeated Economic Indicator
item.description: University of Michigan’s Joanne Hsu can tell US households are in a foul mood. Is anyone listening?
item.dc:creator: Ben Steverman

media:content.media:description: Joanne Hsu in Michigan.

item.title: S. Africa Posts First Successive Primary Surplus in 16 Years
item.description: South Africa achieved its first back-to-back primary budget surplus in 16 years, signaling its commitment to fiscal discipline.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: An outdoor market in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Philippines Cuts 2025 GDP Growth Goal as Tariff Deadline Looms
item.description: The Philippine government cut its economic growth target for this year and expects exports to contract, highlighting lingering trade risks as US President Donald Trump’s tariff deadline nears.
item.dc:creator: Ditas B Lopez, Neil Jerome Morales

media:content.media:description: Manila Light Railway Transit System trains travel along elevated rail tracks in Manila.

item.title: Canada’s Youth Job Market Slumps Most Among Major Economies
item.description: Young Canadians are facing a labor market that has deteriorated faster than in any other major advanced economy.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight, Mario Baker Ramirez

media:content.media:description: One in seven Canadian youth can’t find work.

item.title: Kwacha Rally Drives Zambia Inflation to 14-Month Low
item.description: Zambia’s annual inflation eased to a 14-month low in June after a rally in its currency helped curb the cost of imports.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: A street currency dealer counts US dollars and Zambian kwacha banknotes at a bus station in Lusaka, Zambia, on Friday, Feb. 23, 2024. Zambia’s currency is in its longest winning streak in nearly a year, supported by an unexpectedly large interest-rate hike and a decree that local banks hold back more funds in reserve. Photographer: Luke Dray/Bloomberg

item.title: UK’s Labour Needs to Contain Non-Dom Exodus, Lord Mayor Says
item.description: The UK government should act to stem an exodus of wealthy foreigners from the country following a major tax crackdown, said Alastair King, Lord Mayor of the City of London.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Alastair King

item.title: Korea Overhauls Liquidity Framework to Curb Market Volatility
item.description: The Bank of Korea said it’s revamping its liquidity tools as it seeks to boost its ability to respond during periods of financial market stress.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: South Africans Feel the Pinch as Take-Home Pay Drops
item.description: South Africans real take-home pay declined by 1.1% in May from the previous month, according to BankservAfrica.
item.dc:creator: Zinhle Xaba

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians at the Victoria & Alfred Waterfront neighborhood in Cape Town, South Africa, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. South Africa’s ruling coalition risks unraveling after a dispute between its main members over proposed tax increases deepened, pummeling the rand.

item.title: Israel Long-Term Outlook Helped by Iran War, Central Bank Governor Says
item.description: The war on Iran to curb its military and nuclear program will boost Israel’s long-term economic prospects, according to Central Bank Governor Amir Yaron.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein, Lisa Abramowicz

media:content.media:description: A shopper walks through an outdoor market in Tel Aviv, on June 25.

item.title: Japan Reiterates It Cannot Accept 25% Car Tariffs From US
item.description: Japan’s chief trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said the country can’t accept the US’s 25% tariffs on cars, adding that the Asian nation’s automakers produce far more cars in the US than they export to America.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara
